titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Doty and Young family papers 1977.203
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:16:23 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Doty and Young family papers

physdesc.extent: in one manuscript box and one oversize folder.

did.abstract: This collection includes mortgages, deeds, and agreements relating to various Brooklyn properties owned by Henry D. Young (1841-1884).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. Formally accessioned in 1977.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by family member, subject, and chronologically.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Isaac Doty (1764-1824) married Elizabeth Williams (1760-1820) in 1782. Isaac was the executor of the estate of Thomas Williams, Elizabeth's father, who was a New York City merchant. He was also a proprietor of Doty and Seaman Company, a hardware company, which was established between 1797 and 1801, and Doty, Willets, and Company, a brewery, which was established in 1806. Richard Doty (1783-1852), the son of Isaac, lived in New York City and Brooklyn. He worked with Doty, Willets, and Company and later became Ferry master for the Union Ferry Company. Elizabeth Doty (1810-1862), the daughter of Richard, married Henry D. Young (1841-1884), who was a Brooklyn grocer. Their son, Charles T. Young, was a Brooklyn businessman.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Doty and Young family papers, 1977.203, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was originally minimally processed to the collection level. It was processed to the folder level in April 2023 by Dee Bowers upon discovery of two related certificates in the Brooklyn certificates collection (1977.307), which were added to this collection as part of reprocessing.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Joseph Doty and Jacob Seaman deed (1977.477)
Vincent Tilyou, Mary Tilyou, and Richard Doty deed (1977.496)
William Mott inventory of goods and chattels (1977.485)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes mortgages, deeds, and agreements relating to various Brooklyn properties owned by Henry D. Young. There are also receipts and account books and programs and invitations that pertain to events in Brooklyn. Additional materials include two bank books, deeds, and legal papers of Isaac Doty; an account book for the estate of Thomas Williams; several account books, deeds, certificates and legal papers related to Richard Doty; a notebook of personal accounts with loose papers of the Young and Doty families; a recipe book; invitations and programs of Charles T. Young; and documents regarding the Brooklyn real estate of Henry D. Young.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: If digital surrogates exist, they should be used in place of the originals whenever possible.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.

did.unittitle: Richard Doty documents
Henry D. Young property records - 21 Cheapside Street (Manhattan)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Cheapside Street was renamed Hamilton Street in 1827. The city sold it to the developers of Knickerbocker Village in 1933 and it no longer exists.

did.unittitle: Programs and invitations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brooklyn Bridge opening ceremonies, 1883; 50th anniversary of the incorporation of the City of Brooklyn, 1884; Statue of Liberty inauguration, 1886; and more. Addressed to both Henry D. Young and Charles T. Young.
